title: How to Store Sourdough Starter

steps.headline: Store your sourdough starter in a container with a lid.
steps.description: No matter where you keep your sourdough starter, you will need to make sure that nothing can fall in and contaminate the mixture. A mason jar or plastic container with a lid works well for home bakers. Don't use an airtight container, since the starter needs some air to grow. You can also cover a container loosely with a towel or plastic wrap. A glass container or clear plastic is ideal because you can see inside to monitor the sourdough starter. Keep in mind that a sourdough starter can double in size. Choose a container that is big enough for your starter to grow.

steps.headline: Keep your sourdough starter on your counter to bake with it daily.
steps.description: If you want to make a fresh loaf of sourdough bread every day, you can keep your starter on your kitchen counter. A starter stored at room temperature will always be active and ready for you to bake with it.

steps.headline: Keep your sourdough starter in the fridge if you bake occasionally.
steps.description: If you plan to use your sourdough starter less than daily (or several times a week), keep it in the fridge. It will grow a lot slower and you won't have to feed it as much. You will need to plan ahead to bake with fridge-stored starter. It will take a few hours to come to room temperature before you can bake with it.

steps.headline: Store your starter in the freezer to keep it dormant for up to a year.
steps.description: If you want to take a break from baking for over a month, put your sourdough starter in the freezer. Dry out your starter first, by rolling it out on a piece of parchment paper and leaving it alone for a day or so. Grind the starter into powder in a food processor and then keep it in the freezer. To revive a frozen, dehydrated sourdough starter, add 1 cup (240 mL) of warm, filtered water to the powder and mix it. After a half an hour, check to see if it is too solid or too liquid, and add water or flour to bring it to the right consistency.

steps.headline: Feed room-temperature starter equal weights water and flour.
steps.description: The amount of water and flour you feed your starter depends on how big it is. Weigh your starter and then feed it the same amount of water and flour. For example, if you have around 2/3 cups of starter that weighs 130g, you will need to feed it 2/3 cups of water and 1 cup (130 g) of flour. Use a kitchen scale to measure equal weights of the three ingredients. If your starter is getting too big, simply discard half of it before feeding it. It will quickly grow again.

steps.headline: Feed a room-temperature starter 1-2 times a day.
steps.description: Depending on the temperature of your kitchen, you will need to feed your sourdough starter either once or twice a day. In a cooler kitchen, feed your sourdough starter once a day. Feed it twice a day in a warmer kitchen. An ideal room temperature is around 70 °F (21 °C). Each sourdough starter is a little bit different, so feed it once a day and increase feedings to twice a day if you notice the mixture is starting to get flat and loose bubbles at the end of the day.

steps.headline: Feed a fridge-stored starter weekly.
steps.description: If you bake once a week, you can naturally keep your starter fed and at a manageable size. However, if you don't bake that often, you may need to throw away part of your starter when you feed it to keep it from getting too big. If there is gray water on top of your fridge-stored sourdough starter, that's normal. Just stir it in with the mixture when you feed it. You can go 2 weeks without feeding a starter you store in the fridge, as long as you don't do it too often and you feed it as soon as possible after 2 weeks. Try not to do this more than twice a year.

steps.headline: Dry out your starter using flour to leave it dormant for 2-4 weeks.
steps.description: If you won't be able to feed your starter for a few weeks, mix ⁄3 cup (160 mL) of the starter with 2 cups (260 g) of flour. Work the flour into the starter until it looks like breadcrumbs and store it in a covered container in the fridge. To revive dormant starter, add 1 cup (240 mL) of warm, filtered water to the mixture and let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes.

steps.headline: Look for a domed top with bubbles in a healthy sourdough starter.
steps.description: Typically, a sourdough starter should be a thick liquid mixture, almost too thick to stir. It can be slightly more liquid as long as it looks healthy. A healthy sourdough starter will slowly rise and fall in between feedings, giving it a domed top. The starter should be full of bubbles throughout the day. If your sourdough starter doesn't look healthy, you may need to change the temperature of the room, amount of feedings, or water temperature you use to feed your starter.

text: Choosing the Right Storage Store your sourdough starter in a container with a lid. No matter where you keep your sourdough starter, you will need to make sure that nothing can fall in and contaminate the mixture. A mason jar or plastic container with a lid works well for home bakers. Don't use an airtight container, since the starter needs some air to grow. You can also cover a container loosely with a towel or plastic wrap. A glass container or clear plastic is ideal because you can see inside to monitor the sourdough starter. Keep in mind that a sourdough starter can double in size. Choose a container that is big enough for your starter to grow. Keep your sourdough starter on your counter to bake with it daily. If you want to make a fresh loaf of sourdough bread every day, you can keep your starter on your kitchen counter. A starter stored at room temperature will always be active and ready for you to bake with it. Keep your sourdough starter in the fridge if you bake occasionally. If you plan to use your sourdough starter less than daily (or several times a week), keep it in the fridge. It will grow a lot slower and you won't have to feed it as much. You will need to plan ahead to bake with fridge-stored starter. It will take a few hours to come to room temperature before you can bake with it. Store your starter in the freezer to keep it dormant for up to a year. If you want to take a break from baking for over a month, put your sourdough starter in the freezer. Feeding Your Sourdough Starter Feed room-temperature starter equal weights water and flour. The amount of water and flour you feed your starter depends on how big it is. Use a kitchen scale to measure equal weights of the three ingredients. If your starter is getting too big, simply discard half of it before feeding it. It will quickly grow again. In a cooler kitchen, feed your sourdough starter once a day. Feed it twice a day in a warmer kitchen. An ideal room temperature is around 70 °F (21 °C). Each sourdough starter is a little bit different, so feed it once a day and increase feedings to twice a day if you notice the mixture is starting to get flat and loose bubbles at the end of the day. However, if you don't bake that often, you may need to throw away part of your starter when you feed it to keep it from getting too big. Try not to do this more than twice a year. Dry out your starter using flour to leave it dormant for 2-4 weeks. If you won't be able to feed your starter for a few weeks, mix ⁄3 cup (160 mL) of the starter with 2 cups (260 g) of flour. Work the flour into the starter until it looks like breadcrumbs and store it in a covered container in the fridge. To revive dormant starter, add 1 cup (240 mL) of warm, filtered water to the mixture and let it sit at room temperature for 30 minutes. It can be slightly more liquid as long as it looks healthy. A healthy sourdough starter will slowly rise and fall in between feedings, giving it a domed top. The starter should be full of bubbles throughout the day. If your sourdough starter doesn't look healthy, you may need to change the temperature of the room, amount of feedings, or water temperature you use to feed your starter.

tyn_section: Plastic or glass container with a lid
